content.description: Face to roof with good pro and more face above.

climbs.name: Two for a Peso
climbs.fa: FA Ray Ringle, Herb North 1980 (2 bolts and clean gear), Equipped by Mike Head circa 1990/1

content.description: Start under (in) the tree.  Stout slabby section leads to crystal climbing above.
content.location: Second bolted line from the left end of the wall. Joins up with "West of the Pesos (5.11d)" about halfway up and shares anchors with "Coyote Business". Starts in the same spot as "Coyote Business".

content.description: Easy start, fun route without a well defined crux.  Once the climb goes more vertical (about 25 feet up) the climbing is pretty sustained 5.7 - 5.8 stuff.  Rock quality is somewhat poor, however.
content.location: Second from the right, not listed in Squeezing the Lemmon 2.

content.description:
Enjoy contorting your body into awkward positions and squeezing yourself into tight spaces?  If so this is the climb for you.   

  The crux, which comes early and takes good gear, leads to a wider, featured chimney and moderate, less-than-vertical face climbing.  The latter portions were runout but mild. 

  This climb, like most chimney routes, will appeal to a limited audience.
content.protection:
A wide variety of traditional gear.  I placed everything from a Black Diamond C3 #000 to C4 #5.  Depending on your comfort level you could probably get away with a lot less (and probably squeeze into the chimney a lot easier!).  Use long runners to prevent rope drag. 

  The anchor consists of a single beefy bolt on a mushroom-like feature.  This feature can be lassoed for redundancy. 

  One can walk off or use the anchors of a shorter climb.  I used the anchors of Holey Moley.  Alternatively one could probably rappel off the anchors of Tsunami for a shorter climb.
content.location:
The route ascends the prominent west-facing chimney system, spanning New Wave Wall and Ribbit Wall.   

  Squeezing the Lemmon II lists this route under both walls.

content.description: Tricky face climbing to big roof above.  Obvious bolt line to the left of the Manzanita, but definitely requires gear!
Starts up crack that is Coati Trot then heads left up face.
content.protection: You should take a Yellow Camalot as it will protect moves to the first bolt.
content.location: Starts at the crack/seam and stays left of the seam.

content.description: Semi-bolted line on the far right (east) of Ribbit Wall. A long runout on very easy rock takes you to the first bolt over waves low angle rock. Climb straight up with a mix of trad gear and bolts. Surmount roof on fun holds and amazing feet that you can't see anymore once you commit, and then hop (frog!) up over the lip. Straight up the face to the chains. Short but very fun.
content.protection: draws, slings, nuts, a few cams (.3, 1, 3)

content.description: Slabby start to large undercling.  Work above bulge then up slab and crystal climbing.
content.location: Third bolted line from the left end of the wall. Shares anchors with "Two for a Peso" and "West of the Pesos".  Starts pretty much in the tree.

content.description: Located on the back (south) side of New Wave Wall, Ribbit Wall provides some typical Windy Point slabby, crystally climbing on mostly vertical rock.
